climbs.name: X Files
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant, Mike Draper

content.description: Crux is down low. Slightly overhung arete moves onto a face. Interesting
(Eliminate) Adds a boulder problem (about 10 moves) to the start of New Release and then follows New Release to the end
content.location: If you are staring at the start of Blockbuster (big blocky rail), look right and crawl down as far as you can to find the starting holds for Waiting for Guntess...

content.description:
A short route on mostly jugs, following a right-leaning arch. Small crux, not consistent climbing at the grade.

Climb good pockets up a short vertical face to a right-leaning arch. Follow the arch up and right a little ways, past one single move to a jug, then trend up towards the anchors. The bolts further to the right are for a different route. The route is mostly good pockets, and a huge foot helps through the crux, which is exactly one move. Guidebook calls this an .11a, thats pushing it a lot. Its soft even at .10c.
content.location:
Starts on top of the boulder up and to the right of

Chopping Block

. Theres a hanger just above head height if you stand on the very peak of the boulder. The route that starts down in the cave is a different route.

content.description: Giant crack with great huecos on either side. There are a few burly moves but all huge holds.
content.protection: A couple crash pads and spotters.
content.location: Just past the first creek traverse and before you get to the creek sport climbing areas.

content.description: Begin climbing from the tree, right of "Moonshiner." Easier to traverse in from the left on pockets, than try to battle through the tree to beneath the bulge. Pull the bulge on large pockets to a lower angled area. Continue up the steep face and pull another bulge on pockets to the anchor.
content.location: This route lies between "Moonshiner" and the "Prow" on the northwest face of the Stumbling Block.

climbs.name: The Third Degree
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant, Mike Draper

content.description: Step over a small gap and then trend left up steep face, like most routes at Malibu this route is littered with huecos and good holds
content.location: On the opposite side of the boulder from Letterbox/Nipple Denial Syndrome, first route to the right of the arete. This is now the second route from the left (out of 4 on the face now). The Arete has been bolted.

content.description: roof start, then straight up the arete
content.location: left of Chopping Block. (start is down a bit from the start of Chopping Block).  Belay from tree.

content.description: The route is about 7 or 8 bolts, with the first 4 bolts consisting of overhung face climbing.  After clipping, the 4th bolt start stemming on the boulder behind for two more clips; and then pull of fun buldge/roof move and join the last two bolts of Vigilante to finishing on the same anchors.
content.location: A fun sequece of overhung face climbing that starts down in the pit to the right of Vigilante (or just left of X-Files).

climbs.name: Nipple Denial Syndrome
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant, Mike Draper

content.description:
Shares the same start as

Letterbox

, climb the arete to a large hueco and past it to a slightly less than vertical face. Pumpy, overhanging moves.
content.location:
On the arete, shared start with

Letterbox

content.description: New Release is an eliminate that follows the bolt line of Blockbuster (11a), but avoids the arete in favor of a series of small, sharp pockets.  The crux comes early but the route is relatively sustained for the length. Though it is an eliminate, the line feels natural, and is good fun and worth doing if you're in the area.
content.protection: 5 bolts to anchor (crusty carabiner and open shut).
content.location: Stumbling blocks area, around the corner left of Letterbox, or around and right from Chopping Block. Find Blockbuster and you're there.

content.description:
Located around the corner/arete from

Nipple Denial Syndrome

climb the face up to the arete clipping the last bolt of

Nipple Denial Syndrome

A newer route, still some loose rock on this one. From the big split tree hop up on the rock and head right-ish up the slab past a few good huecos and some awkward moves. The route steepens considerably towards the top to a decent finish.
content.protection:
Five or six bolts to open shuts

Update 5/5/16

[Per Alex Fletcher]: The anchor on this route has been changed. I climbed it on 05/05/2016, and there was only one bolt with a ring on it. Apparently, the old bolts were removed and the holes filled in. Working a few feet to the right allows one to use the two bolts with rings that belong to the route "unknown."
content.location:
From the entrance/chopping block area, traverse left under the roof and squeeze past the big split tree. Start right there in a small space between some rocks. The second to the right of the five routes on the face, left of

Unknown

.

content.description: Clean, easy climbing, good warmup or first lead. Nice and shaded, with only afternoon sun. Not quite vertical with the classic malibu pockets. Be aware that this climb shares an anchor with Chips Ahoy (to the left).
content.protection: 5 bolts to 2 bolt anchor.  As the route starts on a ledge, you really don't want to fall before the first bolt.
content.location: Route starts across from Guerrilla Drilla on the ledge.  Obvious first bolt and less than vertical wall mark the spot.

climbs.name: Letterbox
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant, Mike Draper

content.description:
Shares the start with

Nipple Denial Syndrome

, climb left up the overhanging face on pockets to reach the "letterbox" pull over onto less than vertical face.
Crux is down low.  Fun moves.
content.protection: Anchors up top consisting of two bolts.  Top rope only.  No bolts below the anchors.
content.location: Short overhanging route on a large boulder across the creek from Letter Box, Nipple Denial Syndrome, and Stumbling Blocks area on the way into The Ghetto.

climbs.name: Guerilla Drilla
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant, Mike Draper

content.description: Good holds on less than vertical face leading to a steeper section
content.location: On the next boulder, on the opposite side of X-files, or on the face left of Chopping Block, second route to the right of the arete

content.description: Fun route definitely a worthwhile addition to the wall, a little less pocket pulling and a little more technical through the crux section involving a mini arrete bulge formation about halfway up.
content.protection: First two bolts of The Third Degree make for the start, then move left up 3 more bolts. Anchors.
content.location: The bolted line left of third degree, making it the leftmost route on the wall.

content.description: An ok little warmup in the Stumbling Blocks Area. Short, but surprisingly good holds and moves for the grade. May not be climbable after rain.
content.protection: Top-rope or solo only.  There's two chains at the top.
content.location: It's on the large rock at the foot of the Stumbling Blocks (in front of Chopping Block).  Scramble down into the gulley below to start.

climbs.name: Chopping Block
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal, Matt Oliphant, Mike Draper, 1997

content.description: start from small block with first bolt within reach.  move up and slightly left, then cruise right and then straight up.  avoid moving too far left towads the arete (this is another route)
content.protection: 8 bolts, anchor (1 fixed biner, 1 open shut)
content.location: west-facing, start from small block.  around to the right of Guerilla Drilla.

content.description: A short steep face to start, onto a ledge, then a small roof. After that it's pretty much a 5.6 cruise.
content.location: To the left of (and starts below) Monkey Mayhem. Suggest belaying from tree at base of Monkey Mayhem - rope drag is bad enough there.

content.description:
Fun, consistent climbing at the grade; follows jugs up a right-leaning arête, on a slightly past-vertical wall.

Begin on the face below a right-leaning arête and work up and left through some pockets, passing two bolts, getting to the arête sooner than later. Then just follow the arête up right past a few more bolts to the anchors. There are some hidden jugs on the other side of the arête that youre going to want to find. A little pumpy due to the steepness, but there are no moves difficult for the grade. Ignore a large percentage of the chalked pockets on the face to your right, theyre for an eliminate that follows the line without using the arête (New Release 5.12-)
content.protection: 5 bolts to one open shut and one carabiner
content.location:
Down left towards the creek from

Letterbox

, on the obvious right-leaning arête.
